> Seems like a straightforward fix.
> 
> Can you check which commit introduced `is_cisco_device()` and see if there was some reason mentioned for doing it this way? It seems like just a bug, but might as well check to make sure.
> 
> @yxieca for viz



This is a regression due to https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/15934 (I have given more details at https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/issues/18905) and i don't think there is a reason for doing the change that way.

> > Seems like a straightforward fix.
> > Can you check which commit introduced `is_cisco_device()` and see if there was some reason mentioned for doing it this way? It seems like just a bug, but might as well check to make sure.
> > @yxieca for viz
> 
> This is a regression due to #15934 (I have given more details at #18905) and i don't think there is a reason for doing the change that way.

Yep, agreed, this is just a bug. I did notice in that PR that this change got backported to a couple other releases, we might want to backport this fix there as well.

Cherry-pick PR to 202405: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/16009

Cherry-pick PR to 202411: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/16333

> @shwnaik I remember it was mentioned voq wd need to be disabled only when PFCWD is disabled. Has the situation changed?
> 
> @abdosi for viz.



> @shwnaik I remember it was mentioned voq wd need to be disabled only when PFCWD is disabled. Has the situation changed?
> 
> @abdosi for viz.

@sdszhang updated the PR to disable voqWD in test cases where PFCWD is disabled and tests where traffic is sent for > 1min. voqWD gets triggered if PFC storm is detected for more than 1 min.

@shwnaik we are seeing following errors after merging this PR.

```
......
E File "/usr/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/process.py", line 108, in run
E self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
E File "/var/src/sonic-mgmt_vmsvc5-t2-8800-ixia/tests/snappi_tests/files/helper.py", line 153, in save_config_and_reboot
E if duthost.facts['asic_type'] == "cisco-8000":
E NameError: free variable 'duthost' referenced before assignment in enclosing scope
```

> Hi @developfast , could you add more context on why it should be skipped from PR testing? And now we enabled compatced-area based test, I'm not sure whether removal in the list will actually skip in test.
> 
> 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 parse_prs.py parse_reviews.py pr_dump.sh @yutongzhang-microsoft to confirm, maybe the right way to skip is to assert platform is vs in conditional mark?

The recommended way to skip a test is to use condition mark. The format is documented here https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/common/plugins/conditional_mark/README.md#format-of-the-conditions-file. For this case a `xfail` section needs to be added to `tests_mark_conditions.yaml` with the condition pointing to an open GitHub issue for this failure.

Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

> You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.

There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions:
 def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost):
 config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts']
 bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {})
 pytest_assert(
 wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors),
 "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors)
 )

> @echuawu, please check the formatting issue.

Fixed

> > You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.
> 
> There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions: def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost): config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts'] bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {}) pytest_assert( wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors), "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors) )

That is not sufficient. When I ran this in our lab, this function triggered a runtime error because the BGP daemon was not up yet when the duthost.check_bgp_session_state calls bgp_facts.

> > > You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.
> > 
> > 
> > There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions: def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost): config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts'] bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {}) pytest_assert( wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors), "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors) )
> 
> That is not sufficient. When I ran this in our lab, this function triggered a runtime error because the BGP daemon was not up yet when the duthost.check_bgp_session_state calls bgp_facts.

Do you have any suggestion on this check? Just do not use duthost.check_bgp_session_state?

> > > > You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions: def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost): config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts'] bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {}) pytest_assert( wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors), "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors) )
> > 
> > 
> > That is not sufficient. When I ran this in our lab, this function triggered a runtime error because the BGP daemon was not up yet when the duthost.check_bgp_session_state calls bgp_facts.
> 
> Do you have any suggestion on this check? Just do not use duthost.check_bgp_session_state?

Before the _validate_bgp_session, there is a bgp service check, isn't it enough?
```
with allure.step('Validate BGP docker UP'):
 pytest_assert(wait_until(100, 10, 0, rand_selected_dut.is_service_fully_started_per_asic_or_host,
 "bgp"),
 "BGP not started.")
```

> > > > > You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions: def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost): config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts'] bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {}) pytest_assert( wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors), "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors) )
> > > 
> > > 
> > > That is not sufficient. When I ran this in our lab, this function triggered a runtime error because the BGP daemon was not up yet when the duthost.check_bgp_session_state calls bgp_facts.
> > 
> > 
> > Do you have any suggestion on this check? Just do not use duthost.check_bgp_session_state?
> 
> Before the _validate_bgp_session, there is a bgp service check, isn't it enough?
> 
> ```
> with allure.step('Validate BGP docker UP'):
> pytest_assert(wait_until(100, 10, 0, rand_selected_dut.is_service_fully_started_per_asic_or_host,
> "bgp"),
> "BGP not started.")
> ```

at least not enough in our lab, you can skip checking BGP sessions and add more wait time for checking if the BGP routes are synced

> > > > > > You should use wait_until to validate BGP sessions to avoid failures because BGP daemon not up in time.
> > > > > 
> > > > > 
> > > > > There is wait_until during validation of bgp sessions: def _validate_bgp_session(self, duthost): config_facts = duthost.config_facts(host=duthost.hostname, source="running")['ansible_facts'] bgp_neighbors = config_facts.get('BGP_NEIGHBOR', {}) pytest_assert( wait_until(300, 10, 0, duthost.check_bgp_session_state, bgp_neighbors), "bgp sessions {} are not up".format(bgp_neighbors) )
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > That is not sufficient. When I ran this in our lab, this function triggered a runtime error because the BGP daemon was not up yet when the duthost.check_bgp_session_state calls bgp_facts.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Do you have any suggestion on this check? Just do not use duthost.check_bgp_session_state?
> > 
> > 
> > Before the _validate_bgp_session, there is a bgp service check, isn't it enough?
> > ```
> > with allure.step('Validate BGP docker UP'):
> > pytest_assert(wait_until(100, 10, 0, rand_selected_dut.is_service_fully_started_per_asic_or_host,
> > "bgp"),
> > "BGP not started.")
> > ```
> 
> at least not enough in our lab, you can skip checking BGP sessions and add more wait time for checking if the BGP routes are synced

Updated, please review.

I came across this as I am working on something which is currently dependent on the BGP ASN config which is being restored here. Just curious: was the move away from a common BGP ASN part of a change which will be pushed in the future? Is this something I should be preparing for?
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

> I came across this as I am working on something which is currently dependent on the BGP ASN config which is being restored here. Just curious: was the move away from a common BGP ASN part of a change which will be pushed in the future? Is this something I should be preparing for?

For T0, all the uplink T1 will be in the same ASN. Previously, it was changed by accident in #18224. This PR is fixing it back. There was no intention of moving away from a common BGP ASN for the T1 uplink.

@kamalsahu0001 @selldinesh @YatishSVC for viz.

@sdszhang, I checked it in our platform. Checked for both 100 and 400Gbps, and seeing same behavior.

There is no PFC generated from the DUT in IXIA Tx direction:
```
cat One_Ingress_Egress_pfcwd_drop_90_10_dist400Gbps_sdma-long-to-short-link_1024B-2025-05-10-17-51.txt
-------------- curtailed output ------------------------
Received or Transmitted PFC counts: 
ixr-x3b-14_ethernet0_rx_pfc_3 : 7894022 
ixr-x3b-14_ethernet0_rx_pfc_4 : 7894023 

cat One_Ingress_Egress_pfcwd_drop_uni_dist400Gbps_sdma-long-to-short-link_1024B-2025-05-10-18-48.txt
-------------- curtailed output ------------------------
Received or Transmitted PFC counts: 
ixr-x3b-14_ethernet112_rx_pfc_3 : 7454279 
ixr-x3b-14_ethernet112_rx_pfc_4 : 7454279 
```

> @sdszhang, I checked it in our platform. Checked for both 100 and 400Gbps, and seeing same behavior.
> 
> There is no PFC generated from the DUT in IXIA Tx direction:
> 
> ```
> cat One_Ingress_Egress_pfcwd_drop_90_10_dist400Gbps_sdma-long-to-short-link_1024B-2025-05-10-17-51.txt
> -------------- curtailed output ------------------------
> Received or Transmitted PFC counts: 
> ixr-x3b-14_ethernet0_rx_pfc_3 : 7894022 
> ixr-x3b-14_ethernet0_rx_pfc_4 : 7894023 
> 
> cat One_Ingress_Egress_pfcwd_drop_uni_dist400Gbps_sdma-long-to-short-link_1024B-2025-05-10-18-48.txt
> -------------- curtailed output ------------------------
> Received or Transmitted PFC counts: 
> ixr-x3b-14_ethernet112_rx_pfc_3 : 7454279 
> ixr-x3b-14_ethernet112_rx_pfc_4 : 7454279 
> ```

It's bit unexpected to have no PFC generated towards upstream before PFCWD is being triggered unless there is a big buffer in the chassis to hold all the packets. If that's the case, the current diff will check it for cisco platform only, should be fine to merge.
